questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of right-sided weakness and impaired speech. On admission, she is diagnosed with thrombotic stroke and treatment with alteplase is begun. Neurologic examination four weeks later shows residual right hemiparesis. A CT scan of the head shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following processes best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gangrenous necrosis is most commonly seen in patients with chronic limb ischemia (dry gangrene) and in the gastrointestinal tract (wet gangrene). This patient's infarct was in the brain, which is not subject to gangrenous necrosis.
Image Description:

There are sharply demarcated areas of black, dry, scaly skin on the right medial foot and 1st–3rd toes. Blue discoloration of the 4th toe indicates it is affected by the ischemia as well.

This is the typical appearance of dry gangrene. Dry gangrene is consistent with advanced peripheral arterial disease (Fontaine classification stage IV).

B) INCORRECT:

Coagulative necrosis is the most common type of necrosis and typically results from tissue ischemia in solid organs such as the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys. This patient's infarct was in the brain, which is not subject to coagulative necrosis.
Image Description:

Gross specimen of a spleen post infarction

Multiple infarcts can be seen as lighter-colored areas of coagulative necrosis against the normal dark red splenic tissue. Splenic infarcts are classically subcapsular and wedge-shaped, following the spleen's segmental arterial supply (e.g., infarct in top left).

C) CORRECT:

Infarction in most tissues is associated with coagulative necrosis but brain infarcts cause liquefactive necrosis for reasons that are not completely understood. Liquefactive necrosis begins as early as 24–72 hours most likely as a result of neutrophil infiltration into the infarct zone. Neutrophils release lysosomal enzymes that digest infarcted tissue (“liquefaction”). By 3–5 days, macrophages infiltrate into the infarct zone and begin to phagocytose cellular debris. The late changes associated with liquefactive necrosis are softening of the brain parenchyma (encephalomalacia) and/or the appearance of cystic spaces in the brain. Encephalomalacia causes hypoattenuation of the infarcted region on imaging. In addition to liquefactive necrosis, the infarcted region may also be surrounded by scar tissue due to reactive gliosis by astrocytes.
Image Description:

Frontal brain section (ventral view)

There is a sharply demarcated region of liquefactive necrosis (green overlay) in the right hemisphere. The necrotic area corresponds to the vascular territory of the right middle cerebral artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Caseous necrosis is associated with granulomatous infections such as nocardiosis, tuberculosis, and histoplasmosis. Tuberculous granulomas can affect the CNS but they appear as focal, round or lobulated nodules with surrounding edema. A different type of necrosis is associated with brain infarcts.
Image Description:

Close-up photograph of a lung

Ivory-white, cottage cheese-like lesion within a cavity in the lung tissue (green overlay).

This is the typical macroscopic appearance of caseous necrosis, which is commonly associated with tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis is most commonly seen in blood vessels in patients with vasculitides or malignant hypertension. This patient’s ischemic infarct was in the brain, which is not subject to fibrinoid necrosis.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of arteriole in the lung tissues (H&E stain)

The wall of the arteriole exhibits annular deposition of amorphous and proteinaceous material, and inflammatory infiltrates.

These are the typical features of fibrinoid necrosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis is most commonly seen in patients with acute pancreatitis or traumatic breast lesions. This patient's infarct was in the brain, which is not subject to fat necrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Necrotic adipocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) are visible as adipocytes with indistinct, irregular borders and absent nuclei. Unstained, lipid-filled cystic spaces are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). An inflammatory infiltrate is present (example indicated by arrowhead).

These findings are characteristic of fat necrosis of the breast. At a higher magnification, cholesterol clefts, foam cells, and multinucleated giant cells would also be visible.
questions.hint: This type of necrosis is most commonly associated with bacterial abscesses.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of fever, yellowing of the skin, and nausea for 1 day. He recently returned from a backpacking trip to Brazil and Paraguay, during which he had a 3-day episode of high fever that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows jaundice, epigastric tenderness, and petechiae over his trunk. Five hours after admission, he develops dark brown emesis and anuria. Despite appropriate lifesaving measures, he dies. Postmortem liver biopsy shows eosinophilic degeneration of hepatocytes with condensed nuclear chromatin. This patient’s hepatocytes were most likely undergoing which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Necrosis is the most common mechanism of hepatocellular death in cases of hypoxic or ischemic injury and is characterized by unprogrammed cell death with inflammation. Necrotic hepatocytes appear swollen with prominent membrane blebs and are surrounded by numerous macrophages, unlike the findings that are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Regenerating hepatocytes may occur in response to cellular injury and would appear as mitotic replication surrounded by areas of cell death. This is not consistent with the biopsy findings in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Apoptosis is the process through which hepatocytes respond to certain hepatotoxic insults such as acute viral hepatitis or yellow fever (as seen here). On liver biopsy, apoptotic hepatocytes appear shrunken and deeply eosinophilic with condensed chromatin (pyknosis) and a fragmented nucleus (karyorrhexis).

D) INCORRECT:

Proliferation refers to the rapid division and increase in the number of cells. The proliferation of hepatocytes would be seen with hepatic neoplasms (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma), but would not be expected with yellow fever liver injury. This patient's liver biopsy findings are not consistent with proliferation.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatic steatosis refers to the accumulation of triglycerides and other fats in hepatocytes. Steatosis appears as hepatocytes engorged with fatty droplets and is not consistent with the findings in this patient's biopsy.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is associated with obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance and is the most common cause of liver disease worldwide.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Signs of hepatocellular injury due to steatohepatitis are seen in form of macrovesicular steatosis (large droplet of fat inside hepatocytes; examples indicated by yellow overlay), ballooning degeneration (cellular swelling of hepatocytes; example indicated by dashed outline), and Mallory bodies (hyaline intracytoplasmatic inclusions; examples indicated by arrowheads), combined with a scattered lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (examples indicated by blue overlay).
questions.hint: This patient passed the three clinical stages of yellow fever (infection, remission, intoxication), which is endemic in tropical regions of South America. Liver biopsy shows Councilman bodies, which are typical for yellow fever.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and myalgia. Her boyfriend says she recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. She appears ill and is lethargic. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Physical examination shows jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show the presence of anti-hepatitis A IgM antibodies. A liver biopsy performed at this time would most likely show which of the following histopathological findings?

choices.text: Hepatocytes with shrunken, eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei
Acellular debris surrounded by lymphocytes and macrophages
Cystic spaces with scattered areas of cellular debris
Basophilic adipocyte remnants, filled with calcifications
Engorged hepatocytes with red blood cell infiltration

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hepatocytes with shrunken, eosinophilic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei are the histopathological characteristics of Councilman bodies. Councilman bodies are remnants of apoptotic hepatocytes and can be found in patients with acute hepatitis A. Apoptosis of virus-infected cells, such as HAV-infected hepatocytes, is induced by the release of granzyme B and perforin from cytotoxic T cells (the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis). Other histopathological signs in patients with hepatitis A include ballooning degeneration (swelling of hepatocytes) and bridging necrosis (confluent necrosis spanning adjacent lobules).

B) INCORRECT:

Acellular debris with encapsulating inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes and macrophages, is characteristic of caseous necrosis. This process is typically seen in tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, cryptococcosis, and coccidioidomycosis, each of which could cause focal necrosis in the liver. However, hepatitis A is not associated with the formation of caseous necrosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

The image shows a granuloma with necrosis in the center (green outline), a surrounding layer of immune cells such as macrophages (B), and a peripheral layer (C), which consists of epitheloid cells. A giant cell (A) can also be seen.

This is the typical histopathological appearance of a caseating granuloma, which is seen in tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of cystic space and cellular debris is characteristic of liquefactive necrosis. Liquefaction is due to the release of neutrophilic enzymes that degrade tissue into a liquid, viscous mass. Liquefactive necrosis is commonly seen in bacterial abscesses and brain infarcts. However, it rarely occurs in the liver and in conjunction with a viral infection such as hepatitis A.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (H&E stain)

Numerous cystic spaces and disintegration of the normal tissue architecture are visible. There is abundant cellular debris.

The extensive transformation of the tissue differentiates this case of liquefactive necrosis from one of coagulative necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Remnants of basophilic adipocytes with calcification are characteristic of fat necrosis. Fat necrosis occurs due to the release of lipases that degrade triglycerides, causing saponification. This process is seen in the acute inflammation or trauma of tissue with a high concentration of adipocytes (e.g., pancreas, breast).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Necrotic adipocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) are visible as adipocytes with indistinct, irregular borders and absent nuclei. Unstained, lipid-filled cystic spaces are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). An inflammatory infiltrate is present (example indicated by arrowhead).

These findings are characteristic of fat necrosis of the breast. At a higher magnification, cholesterol clefts, foam cells, and multinucleated giant cells would also be visible.

E) INCORRECT:

Engorged hepatocytes with RBC infiltration can be seen in hemorrhagic infarcts (red infarcts) of the liver. Hemorrhagic infarcts occur in organs with dual blood supply (e.g., lung, GI tract, testes, and liver), secondary to occlusion of vessels and subsequent extravasation of RBCs into the ischemic tissue. This finding would not be explained by a viral infection such as hepatitis A.
questions.hint: This patient has acute hepatitis A and biopsy is likely to show findings consistent with apoptosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician a week after noticing a lump in her left breast. Three months ago, she was discharged from the hospital after treatment of multiple injuries sustained in a motor vehicle collision. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother died of ovarian cancer. Examination shows a 2.5-cm, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Mammography shows a circumscribed radiolucent lesion with a rim of peripheral calcification. A photomicrograph of tissue from a biopsy of the mass is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the breast swelling?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast (Mondor disease) can occur secondary to trauma. However, it would manifest as a tender, palpable superficial cord on the anterolateral surface of the breast and not as the painless lump seen here. Mammography, though not typically done in Mondor disease, would show a superficial tubular hypodense lesion. A biopsy would show a thrombosed vein and acute inflammatory infiltrate, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of estrogen receptors is the underlying cause for the development of fibroadenoma, fibrocystic breast changes, and ER-positive breast cancer. All three of these conditions may present with a painless breast lump and calcifications on mammography, as seen in this patient. However, a fibroadenoma would show proliferation of glandular and stromal tissue on histopathology, while fibrocystic breast changes often cause nipple discharge, show numerous small cysts on mammography, and appear as proliferation of small ductules and acini in lobules on histopathology. Breast cancer is also unlikely because it would appear as an ill-defined mass with irregular microcalcifications on mammography, and cells with features of malignant transformation (e.g., hyperchromatism, mitotic figures) in the ducts or lobules on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective DNA repair is the underlying cause of hereditary breast cancer syndromes (e.g., BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, Lynch syndrome). Breast cancer can manifest as a painless breast lump and this patient has a high risk of developing breast cancer based on her age and family history of ovarian cancer. However, breast cancer would typically appear on mammography as an ill-defined mass with irregular microcalcifications and not as the circumscribed radiolucent lesion seen here. Moreover, cells with features of malignant transformation (e.g., hyperchromatism, mitotic figures, nuclear pleomorphism) would have been present in the ducts or lobules on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a surgical sample of breast tissue (H&E stain, low magnification)

An area of sclerosis (light purple) is visible in the center of the invasive ductal carcinoma (dark purple).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of lactiferous ducts can result in a palpable breast lump due to breast abscess, a complication of mastitis. Breast abscess typically manifests as a tender breast lump with signs of inflammation (erythema, warmth, and tenderness) in lactating women. This patient's lump, however, is nontender, and she is not lactating. Mammography of breast abscess, though not typically performed, would show a heterogenic mass without calcification, in contrast to the calcification seen here. Biopsy would show an acute inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils and cellular debris (liquefactive necrosis).

E) CORRECT:

Release of cytoplasmic triglycerides causes fat necrosis of the breast, which typically occurs following trauma, such as that sustained by this patient. Trauma damages adipocytes in breast tissue, spilling lipase and triglycerides into the interstitium. Triglycerides are then broken down by lipase into free fatty acids that bind with calcium to form calcium salts (saponification). The resulting inflammatory process walls off the injury as an oil cyst surrounded by necrotic, anucleate adipocytes; foam cells; and other inflammatory cells, as in the biopsy here. Fat necrosis of the breast can resemble malignancy on physical examination (painless lump) and/or imaging (calcifications), often making histological confirmation necessary.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the cell morphologies of the respiratory tract. He obtains a biopsy from the mainstem bronchus of a patient. On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows uniform squamous cells in layers. Which of the following best describes the histologic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Metaplasia is a non-neoplastic and reversible transformation of a mature cell type into another cell type that is not native to that specific region. This usually occurs as a protective mechanism to adapt to chronic irritation or cell injury. The normal bronchial epithelium is composed of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with numerous mucus-secreting goblet cells. The stratified squamous epithelium seen on this patient's biopsy is not native to the bronchial tree and is a sign of metaplastic stem cell reprogramming (squamous metaplasia), most likely due to chronic smoking. Other examples of metaplasia are Barrett esophagus (due to chronic exposure to gastric acid) and myositis ossificans. If chronic irritation persists, dysplastic changes (e.g., cellular atypia, numerous mitotic figures, increased N:C ratio) can occur in metaplastic tissue.
Image Description:

Cells demonstrate particular adaptive changes in response to environmental changes or increased or decreased tissue requirements.

Cells can increase in size but not in number as a response to increased demand, which is termed hypertrophy (e.g., in skeletal muscles as a response to muscle training; top of the image). Hyperplasia is an increase in cell number with unaltered cell size (e.g., the thyroid in persistent iodine deficiency; middle left). There are two types of atrophy. Atrophy (bottom left) is a decrease in cell number, whereas hypotrophy (cellular atrophy; bottom right) is a decrease in cell size. If cell differentiation is affected as a result of cellular adaptation, this is termed metaplasia (e.g., transformation of squamous epithelium into cylindrical, mucosal epithelium in chronic gastric acid reflux in the esophagus; middle right).

B) INCORRECT:

Normal bronchial epithelium is composed of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with numerous mucin-secreting goblet cells (respiratory epithelium). Squamous cells such as type I pneumocytes are seen in the alveoli but are not normally found in the bronchial tree.
Image Description:

Branches of the pulmonary artery carry oxygen-depleted blood to the alveoli for oxygen enrichment (hence depicted in blue), while branches of the pulmonary vein carry oxygen-rich blood from the lungs to the heart (depicted in red).

C) INCORRECT:

Dysplasia is a pre-malignant, disordered change in the growth of native epithelium, usually secondary to chronic irritation or infection. Although this patient's bronchus has been exposed to chronic irritation from smoke inhalation, his bronchial biopsy shows uniform squamous epithelium without features of dysplasia (e.g., pleomorphism, increased N:C ratio, disordered growth).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of squamous cells of the cervix (Papanicolaou stain; very high magnification;)

There is a loosely connected group of abnormal squamous epithelial cells (blue-green cytoplasm). The nuclei are variable in size with a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio and there are course clumps of chromatin. The large cell with pink cytoplasm is a normal superficial squamous cell.

These findings are characteristic of severe dysplasia as seen in high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL).

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperplasia involves a benign increase in the number of cells native to a particular region of the body. Epithelial hyperplasia can result from chronic irritation by cigarette smoke. It can also eventually lead to malignancy, as seen in the example of endometrial hyperplasia, which can develop into endometrial cancer. However, this patient's bronchial biopsy shows squamous epithelium, which is not native to the bronchial tree and therefore could not have appeared here by a process of hyperplasia.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of the endometrium (H&E stain)

Endometrial tissue obtained via fractional curettage. The glandular cystic endometrial hyperplasia is characterized by an increase in both stromal and glandular cells. Enlarged, dilated mucosal glands (swiss cheese pattern) are located between the abundant stromal tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy involves an increase in the size of cells native to a particular region of the body and typically occurs secondary to increased workload (e.g., left ventricular hypertrophy in chronic hypertension). However, this patient's bronchial biopsy shows squamous epithelium, which is not native to the bronchial tree and therefore could not have appeared here by a process of hypertrophy.
Image Description:

Four transverse slices of the heart

There is concentric hypertrophy (indicated by arrows) of the left ventricular myocardium (green overlay), which has narrowed the lumen (red overlay) and caused a reduction in the intraventricular volume.

F) INCORRECT:

Anaplasia involves complete loss of differentiation and is characteristic of high-grade malignancy (e.g., anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, small cell lung carcinoma). The biopsy in this patient shows squamous differentiation, not anaplasia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

questions.text: A 78-year-old man dies suddenly from complications of acute kidney failure. An autopsy is performed and microscopic evaluation of the kidneys shows pale, swollen cells in the proximal convoluted tubules. Microscopic evaluation of the liver shows similar findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The release of cytochrome C from the inner mitochondrial membrane into the cytoplasm is part of the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis. Histologic findings associated with apoptosis include cell shrinkage (rather than cell swelling), pyknosis, karyorrhexis, deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm, and basophilic nucleus on microscopic examination. Prolonged tissue hypoxia and irreversible cell injury can lead to apoptosis, but the microscopic findings seen here are more characteristic of a different mechanism.

B) CORRECT:

Hydropic degeneration refers to the pale, swollen cells seen on light microscopy in response to tissue hypoxia. Tissue hypoxia (in this case, likely due to impaired renal perfusion, given the history of acute kidney injury) leads to a decrease in ATP production in the affected tissue, which impairs the cellular Na+/K+-ATPase pump, which is dependent on ATP. As a result, Na+(and water) accumulate in the cell, leading to cell swelling as seen here. This process can potentially be reversible if the hypoxia resolves, but prolonged hypoxia results in irreversible cell damage and apoptosis. The proximal convoluted tubules are especially sensitive to tissue hypoxia and are often the first cells affected in states of decreased blood flow.

C) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of cytoplasmic triglycerides in the liver is seen with hepatic steatosis. Hepatic steatosis does not cause acute kidney failure, and, unlike this patient's microscopic findings, the triglycerides would manifest as vacuoles in the hepatocytes.

D) INCORRECT:

Breaks in double-stranded DNA typically occur due to ionizing radiation and are apoptosis-triggering lesions. Therefore, the morphological changes would be much more likely to include cell shrinkage (rather than cell swelling), pyknosis, karyorrhexis, deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm, and basophilic nucleus.

E) INCORRECT:

Free radical formation leads to cell damage via various mechanisms (e.g., membrane lipid peroxidation, protein modification, DNA breakage) and can occur in response to radiation exposure, drug metabolism, redox reactions, and inflammation. Unlike this patient's findings, the histological findings seen in free radical injury typically consist of shrunken, necrotic cells rather than the swollen cells seen here.
questions.hint: Pale and swollen cells suggest hydropic degeneration, one of the first microscopic signs of tissue hypoxia.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of involuntary weight loss and a painless lump on her neck. Physical examination shows a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of the neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland shows a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. A biopsy of the thyroid nodule is performed. Which of the following changes would be most consistent with anaplasia?

choices.text: Negative staining of tumor cells for thyroglobulin
Replacement of thyroid cells by normal squamous epithelium
Reduced number of functional thyroid cells
Disorganized proliferation of mature thyroid cells
Increased expression of thyroid transcription factor-1

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anaplasia is a process in which cells lose their function and structural differentiation. They may resemble primitive, undifferentiated cells of the tissue they originated from and manifest as large cells with several nuclei or a single large nucleus. Thyroglobulin is a precursor to thyroid hormones that is produced by mature thyroid cells and stored in follicles of the thyroid. Undifferentiated (i.e., anaplastic) thyroid cells lose their ability to produce thyroglobulin. A negative stain for thyroglobulin would, therefore, be a sign of anaplasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Replacement of thyroid cells by normal squamous epithelium is consistent with metaplasia, a reversible transformation of a mature cell type into another cell type that is not native to that specific region. However, in anaplasia, cells are no longer differentiated into any cell type.

C) INCORRECT:

A reduced number of functional thyroid cells is consistent with hypoplasia, which is a decrease in tissue mass due to a reduction in the number of (differentiated) cells. However, in anaplasia, the number of functional thyroid cells is normal. Instead, a small number of cells dedifferentiate into anaplastic cells, which proliferate independently into tumors.

D) INCORRECT:

Disorganized proliferation of thyroid cells is consistent with dysplasia, a disorder of cell growth characterized by abnormally frequent mitotic figures and loss of cell orientation and uniformity (size, shape). However, in dysplasia, cells remain differentiated, while in anaplasia they do not.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased expression of thyroid transcription factor-1 may be seen in follicular, papillary, and medullary thyroid carcinomas. However, in anaplasia, which is characterized by a loss of cellular differentiation, expression of this transcription factor would be decreased.
questions.hint: Anaplasia is the loss of cellular differentiation.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the normal process of shrinking of the thymus gland with increasing age in humans. Thymic size is found to gradually start decreasing during puberty. Which of the following enzymes is most likely involved in the process underlying the decline in thymus mass with aging?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lipase is an enzyme typically involved in the breakdown of triglycerides in adipose cells. Lipase overactivity can lead to fat necrosis. However, it is not involved in apoptosis, which is the mechanism behind thymic involution.

B) INCORRECT:

Metalloproteinases (MMPs) are enzymes that break down extracellular matrix proteins, particularly during wound healing and remodeling. Their expression is regulated by a balance between transforming growth factor beta and pro-inflammatory markers such as tumor necrosis factor alpha and IL-1. Dysregulation of MMPs is also involved in tumor invasion occurring through the basement membrane. However, MMPs are not involved in apoptosis.

C) CORRECT:

Caspases (Cysteine-ASpartic ProteASES) are a group of enzymes that cleave proteins and peptides and attack the cell membrane, nucleus, and cytoplasm. They are involved in both the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis (triggered by death factors such as Fas ligand and tumor necrosis factor alpha) and the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis (typically triggered by mitochondrial changes). Initiator caspases are activated first, which then activate executioner caspases, which execute apoptosis.

The thymus plays a crucial role in the maturation and differentiation of T lymphocytes during infancy and childhood. Beginning in puberty, the thymus physiologically undergoes involution, i.e., it becomes atrophied and is replaced by fatty tissue.
Image Description:

Apoptosis is a type of programmed cell death that is carried out by a set of intracellular protease enzymes known as caspases, which are activated via two pathways:

1. The extrinsic (death receptor) pathway involves the activation of caspases brought about either by the binding of certain ligands to their receptors (e.g., FasL to Fas) or by cytotoxic T cells introducing proteases (e.g., perforin, granzyme B) into cells. The ligand-receptor complex activates initiator caspase 8 and the proteases activate the initiator caspase 10.

2. The intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway involves the activation of caspases by a wheel-like structure, known as an apoptosome. This pathway is initiated by DNA injury (e.g., radiation, toxins) or the withdrawal of cellular proliferating factors (e.g., IL-2), which activates pro-apoptotic factors (BAX and BAK) and inhibits anti-apoptotic factors (Bcl-2). Pro-apoptotic factors increase mitochondrial membrane permeability, thus releasing cytochrome C, which then binds to APAF-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor 1), forming an apoptosome that activates the initiator caspase 9.

3. Common pathway: The initiator caspases activate the executioner caspases (3,6,7), which then cause nuclear fragmentation and cytoskeletal disintegration, resulting in cell shrinkage and membrane blebbing. These blebs carrying disintegrated cellular material break away from the cell, forming apoptotic bodies that are phagocytosed by macrophages.

D) INCORRECT:

NADPH oxidase is critical for the respiratory burst used by neutrophils to kill pathogens. While NADPH is important for immune function, it plays no role in thymic involution, which is an apoptotic process.

E) INCORRECT:

Collagenases play a critical role in unwinding and cleaving the collagen triple helix during normal wound healing and remodeling. Pathologic dysregulation of collagenase during tumor expansion can compromise the basement membrane between the dermis and epidermis, facilitating tumor invasion and metastasis. However, collagenase is not involved in apoptosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Lipoxygenases are a family of enzymes that convert arachidonic acid to leukotriene B4. Leukotriene B4 is a pro-inflammatory signaling molecule that stimulates the production of prostaglandins or histamines by neighboring cells. While thymic involution has been shown to be influenced by environmental factors, this process is not inflammatory but rather induced by apoptosis.
questions.hint: Thymic involution is the result of apoptosis, i.e., programmed, enzyme-mediated cell death.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the interaction between epithelial cells and calcium ion concentration. When the calcium ion concentration available to a sample of epithelial tissue is decreased, an increased gap between adjacent epithelial cells is seen on electron microscopy. This observed decrease in cell adhesion is most likely due to an effect on which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Claudins, along with occludin, are involved in the formation of tight (or occluding) junctions. Tight junctions seal adjacent epithelial cells together and prevent paracellular movement of ions and molecules. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

B) CORRECT:

Cadherins (or calcium-dependent adhesion protein) are a family of cell adhesion molecules that contribute to the formation of adherens junctions, which connect the actin cytoskeletons of adjacent cells. A lack of calcium ions would cause a loss of cadherins, leading to an increased gap between epithelial cells. Cadherins are also major cell-cell adhesion molecules in tumors. During tumor progression, the loss or alteration of cadherin function causes disaggregation of cancer cells from primary tumors, promoting invasion and metastasis of tumor cells.
Image Description:

The different cell junction types differ in their molecular structure; however, they all contain certain types of transmembrane proteins. The transmembrane proteins of the zonula adhaerens, desmosomes, and hemidesmosomes are connected to a component of the cytoskeleton, but also to structures external to the cell. The tight junction proteins claudin and occludin are linked to actin filaments of the cytoskeleton by additional proteins (not shown). Their extracellular domains interact with one another and close the gaps between epithelial cells. Gap junctions are similar to ion channels in that they are permeable to small molecules and alternate between open and closed states. In addition to their communication function, gap junctions support the adhesion of neighboring cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Actin filaments are important parts of the cytoskeleton that are involved in adhesion, as they connect to cadherins and form adherens junctions. However, they are are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytokeratins are a family of intermediate filaments that interact to form desmosomes, which connect cells to one another. However, cytokeratin is not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

E) INCORRECT:

Connexons are channels with a central pore formed from six membrane-spanning proteins called connexins. Two neighboring connexons form a gap junction, which permits the passage of electrical and chemical signals between cells. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level. Moreover, connexons are not involved in cell adhesion.

F) INCORRECT:

Laminins are a major component of the basal lamina. They contribute to cell attachment and differentiation as well as cell shape and movement. They also help maintain tissue phenotype and promote tissue survival. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

G) INCORRECT:

Integrins are membrane proteins that bind to collagen, laminin, and fibronectin in the basement membrane, lending structural integrity to the basolateral membrane. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level. Moreover, integrins are not involved in cell-cell adhesion.
questions.hint: Loss of this protein can promote metastasis of malignant cells.

questions.text: During an experiment, an investigator attempts to determine the rates of apoptosis in various tissue samples. Injecting cytotoxic T cells into the cell culture of one of the samples causes the tissue cells to undergo apoptosis. Apoptosis is most likely due to secretion of which of the following substances in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytochrome C is released from the inner mitochondrial membrane upon activation of apoptosis via the BAX/Bcl-2 pathway. It activates initiator caspases, which in turn activate executioner caspases, leading to degradation of cellular components. However, cytochrome C is part of the intrinsic apoptotic pathway, which is not induced by cytotoxic T cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Bcl-2 is involved in the regulation of apoptosis. However, it is an antiapoptotic molecule that inhibits intrinsic apoptotic pathway via inhibition of cytochrome C release. Therefore, it neither causes cell death nor is it induced by cytotoxic T cells.

C) INCORRECT:

TNF-α is involved in the extrinsic apoptotic pathway. It binds to the TNF receptor (receptor-mediated apoptosis), which activates initiator caspases. The initiator caspases activate executioner caspases, leading to degradation of cellular components. However, cytotoxic T cells are not involved in this process.

D) INCORRECT:

BAX is a proapoptotic protein that activates cytochrome C, which then activates initiator caspases. The initiator caspases activate executioner caspases, leading to the degradation of cellular components. BAX, however, is part of the intrinsic apoptotic pathway, which is not induced by cytotoxic T cells.

E) CORRECT:

Cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells recognize target cells (most commonly virally infected and malignant cells) via MHC class I antigen presentation. This induces activation of the extrinsic apoptotic pathway via the release of cytotoxic proteins, including granzymes (especially granzyme B) and perforin. Perforins cause pores to form in the membrane of cells, which enable granzymes to enter the cytoplasm. Granzyme B then activates executioner caspases (especially caspase-3), which cleave many substrates, causing degradation of cellular components. Finally, the degraded abnormal target cell (apoptotic cell) can be removed via macrophage phagocytosis.
Image Description:

Apoptosis is a type of programmed cell death that is carried out by a set of intracellular protease enzymes known as caspases, which are activated via two pathways:

1. The extrinsic (death receptor) pathway involves the activation of caspases brought about either by the binding of certain ligands to their receptors (e.g., FasL to Fas) or by cytotoxic T cells introducing proteases (e.g., perforin, granzyme B) into cells. The ligand-receptor complex activates initiator caspase 8 and the proteases activate the initiator caspase 10.

2. The intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway involves the activation of caspases by a wheel-like structure, known as an apoptosome. This pathway is initiated by DNA injury (e.g., radiation, toxins) or the withdrawal of cellular proliferating factors (e.g., IL-2), which activates pro-apoptotic factors (BAX and BAK) and inhibits anti-apoptotic factors (Bcl-2). Pro-apoptotic factors increase mitochondrial membrane permeability, thus releasing cytochrome C, which then binds to APAF-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor 1), forming an apoptosome that activates the initiator caspase 9.

3. Common pathway: The initiator caspases activate the executioner caspases (3,6,7), which then cause nuclear fragmentation and cytoskeletal disintegration, resulting in cell shrinkage and membrane blebbing. These blebs carrying disintegrated cellular material break away from the cell, forming apoptotic bodies that are phagocytosed by macrophages.

F) INCORRECT:

Caspases are a major component of both the intrinsic and the extrinsic apoptotic pathways, as they cause degradation of cellular components. T cell-mediated apoptosis will ultimately result in the activation and release of caspases. However, caspases are not secreted by cytotoxic T cells.

G) INCORRECT:

Cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis in target cells by expressing FasL onto their cell membranes. FasL binds the Fas receptor (receptor-mediated apoptosis), which activates initiator caspases in the extrinsic apoptotic pathway. The initiator caspases activate executioner caspases, leading to the degradation of cellular components. FasL, however, is bound to the cell membrane and is not secreted by cytotoxic T cells.
questions.hint: Cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis via an extrinsic signaling pathway.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of lower abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. He has a history of constipation. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Abdominal examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 19,000/mm3. A CT scan of the abdomen shows segmental wall thickening of the descending colon with multiple diverticula and a 5.0-cm, low-attenuation pelvic lesion with air-fluid levels. CT-guided drainage of the fluid collection yields 250 mL of yellow-greenish fluid. Release of which of the following substances is most likely responsible for the formation of the drained lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal coagulase is an enzyme produced by Staphylococcus aureus. This enzyme helps speeds up the process of building a fibrinogen wall around an abscess by converting fibrinogen to fibrin. However, it is not responsible for abscess formation itself and does not account for the involvement of gram-negative bacteria. S. aureus is also rarely implicated in colonic infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Major basic protein is one of several cationic proteins associated with the eosinophil granule. This protein is cytotoxic to respiratory epithelium and is present in the sputum of individuals with asthma. It is also involved in host defense against helminths and parasites but does not play a role in suppurative inflammation or liquefactive necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

IFN-γ is a cell signaling protein that mediates macrophage activity and the expression of MHC molecules. IFN-γ does not play a role in purulent exudate formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipoteichoic acid (LTA) is anchored in the cytoplasmic membrane of all gram-positive bacteria and extends to the outer cell wall. There, LTA acts as an antigen that induces TNF-α and IL-1. Although both of these are key signaling cytokines involved in abscess formation, this reaction does not require the release of LTA. In addition, LTA does not account for the involvement of gram-negative bacteria, which are very likely to be involved in colon-derived intra-abdominal abscesses.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactic acid is an endogenous non-toxic molecule and an energetic substrate of gluconeogenesis. Lactic acid levels may be elevated in coagulative necrosis due to a tissue hypoxia, but lactic acid does not play a role in purulent exudate formation.

F) INCORRECT:

IL-3 is a cytokine that supports the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic stem cells. It is not involved in suppurative inflammation or liquefactive necrosis.

Interleukin 1 and 6 are key cytokines involved in abscess formation.

G) INCORRECT:

Histamine is a vasoactive amine and inflammatory mediatory that is released during mast cell degranulation in response to primarily injury, pathogens, or allergens. It does not play a role in purulent exudate formation.

H) CORRECT:

Lysosomal enzymes released by neutrophils and macrophages are responsible for abscess formation. These enzymes dissolve dead cells and kill bacteria in an acute inflammatory process known as suppurative inflammation, which leads to liquefactive necrosis and abscess formation.
questions.hint: The constellation of constipation, lower quadrant pain, and segmental colonic wall thickening with multiple diverticula and surrounding fat stranding indicates acute diverticulitis. The diverticulitis is complicated by an intra-abdominal abscess (low-attenuation pelvic lesion with air-fluid levels) that likely involves gram-negative bacteria like Bacteroides and E. coli, the most dominant types in the colon. The pus in an abscess is due to the dissolution of dead tissue and its transformation into a viscous mass, which is characteristic of liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation of chronic, retrosternal chest pain. The pain is worse at night and after heavy meals. He has taken oral pantoprazole for several months without any relief of his symptoms. Upper endoscopy shows ulcerations in the distal esophagus and a proximally dislocated Z-line. A biopsy of the distal esophagus shows mature columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following microscopic findings underlies the same pathomechanism as the cellular changes seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium in the bronchi
Branching muscularis mucosa in the jejunum
Simple columnar epithelium in the endocervix

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of pseudostratified columnar epithelium in the bronchi (and the trachea) is a normal finding. In contrast, Barrett esophagus is an example of metaplasia. The presence of stratified squamous epithelium in the bronchi (e.g., from chronic smoke exposure) would be an example of metaplasia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tracheal biopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Cell layers (from top to bottom):
– Mucosa: ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium with numerous goblet cells, resting on lamina propria, which contains elastic fibers and connective tissue
– Detail: cilia (example indicated by green overlay), nuclei (examples indicated by white arrowheads), goblet cell (examples indicated by orange overlay)
– Submucosa: numerous seromucous glands (black arrow) and smooth muscle cells with lamina propria underneath
– Hyaline cartilage: chondrocytes and lacunae surrounded by an extracellular matrix (grey overlay)
Adventitia: loose areolar tissue (white band on the bottom right)

B) CORRECT:

The bladder is normally lined by transitional epithelium. Chronic irritation of the bladder wall (e.g., from Schistosoma infection, urinary calculi, or indwelling catheters) can result in a transformation of transitional to squamous epithelium. Cellular transformation due to chronic stress (metaplasia) occurs when stem cells reprogram to replace one mature cell type with another that adapts to the chronic stress. Early metaplastic changes are reversible if exposure to the irritant stops. However, dysplastic changes can occur if chronic irritation persists.
Image Description:

Cells demonstrate particular adaptive changes in response to environmental changes or increased or decreased tissue requirements.

Cells can increase in size but not in number as a response to increased demand, which is termed hypertrophy (e.g., in skeletal muscles as a response to muscle training; top of the image). Hyperplasia is an increase in cell number with unaltered cell size (e.g., the thyroid in persistent iodine deficiency; middle left). There are two types of atrophy. Atrophy (bottom left) is a decrease in cell number, whereas hypotrophy (cellular atrophy; bottom right) is a decrease in cell size. If cell differentiation is affected as a result of cellular adaptation, this is termed metaplasia (e.g., transformation of squamous epithelium into cylindrical, mucosal epithelium in chronic gastric acid reflux in the esophagus; middle right).

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of Paneth cells in the duodenum is a normal finding. In contrast, Barrett esophagus is an example of metaplasia. The presence of Paneth cells in the stomach (e.g., as a result of chronic H. pylori infection) would be an example of metaplasia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of duodenal mucosa (H&E stain; 300x magnification)

Numerous cells with eosinophilic granules in their cytoplasm are visible within the mucosal crypts (examples indicated by green overlay). These cells, known as Paneth cells, store antipathogenic defensins and lysozyme in their granules.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Branching of the muscularis mucosa is a characteristic feature of hamartomatous polyps, which are associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and can occur at any location along the gastrointestinal tract. Hamartomas are disorganized overgrowths of tissue in their native location. Barrett esophagus is characterized by metaplasia, not hamartomas.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a colonic polyp (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

Hyperplastic smooth muscle cells (uninucleated spindle-shaped cells) are visible as broad pink bands arranged in a tree-like pattern. Glandular hyperplasia without distortion of the normal tissue architecture is also visible.

These features are consistent with a hamartomatous polyp, which is typically seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of gastric chief cells in the ileum can be seen in some forms of Meckel diverticulum. A Meckel diverticulum with gastric tissue is an example of a choristoma, which refers to an ectopic island of normal tissue in an abnormal location. Choristomas are the result of metaplastic changes during embryonic development. In contrast, Barrett esophagus is characterized by postnatal metaplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

The presence of simple columnar epithelium in the endocervix is a normal finding. In contrast, Barrett esophagus is an example of metaplasia. The endocervix physiologically undergoes metaplasia in the cervical transformation zone (squamocolumnar junction), where the simple columnar epithelium develops into squamous epithelium as a result of exposure to the acid vaginal pH.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cervical tissue (H&E stain; 25x magnification)

The image shows the junction between the cervical canal (top) and the vagina (bottom), where the simple columnar squamous mucosal epithelium of the endometrium transitions to the nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the vaginal mucosa.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: The biopsy findings in this patient (columnar epithelium with goblet cells) confirm a diagnosis of Barrett esophagus, which is characterized by metaplasia from squamous epithelium to intestinal columnar epithelium as a result of chronic gastric acid exposure.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 4 hours after the sudden onset of excruciating pain in his right calf. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The right foot is cold and pale, and palpation of the right posterior tibial artery shows no pulse. Muscle strength is 1/5 and sensation to touch is significantly decreased in the right lower extremity. His serum creatine kinase concentration is elevated. Arterial duplex sonography shows absent blood flow distal to the right popliteal artery. Compared with a healthy adult, which of the following sets of intracellular electrolyte concentrations are most likely to be found in this patient's right distal gastrocnemius muscle?



Na+

K+

Ca2+




A
↑
↓
normal


B
↑
↑
↑


C
↓
↑
normal


D
↓
↓
normal


E
↑
↓
↑
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The constellation of increased sodium, decreased potassium, and normal calcium is consistent with acute cellular ischemia. Because ischemic muscle cells rely on anaerobic metabolism, they quickly deplete their supply of ATP, leading to lactic acidosis and early symptoms of limb ischemia. The affected cells counteract this acidosis by activating sodium-hydrogen exchangers, causing intracellular sodium levels to rise. Intracellular potassium levels also increase, but the mechanism is unknown. Mild muscle weakness, minimal sensory loss, and no paresthesia is expected in patients with acute limb ischemia, as neurons are still intact. This patient, however, has pain, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis. Moreover, because muscle cells are not yet irreversibly damaged in the acute phase of an ischemic event, elevated serum creatine kinase levels are not expected.

B) INCORRECT:

The constellation of increased sodium, potassium, and calcium is seen in reperfusion injury of irreversibly damaged muscle. Reperfusion injury typically occurs hours to days after the blood supply is restored to an ischemic muscle and is mostly due to the generation of free radicals and intracellular calcium overload. This patient, however, is at a prolonged stage of limb ischemia and perfusion to the muscle has not yet been restored. Therefore, another set of findings is expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The constellation of decreased sodium, elevated potassium, and unaltered calcium is not consistent with any stage of ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of unaltered calcium and decreased sodium and potassium is not consistent with any stage of ischemia.

E) CORRECT:

This constellation of changes is consistent with late limb ischemia, a stage at which the muscle cells have been irreversibly damaged and necrosis has begun. Once the cells' supply of ATP is depleted, energy-dependent cellular functions decrease, including Na+-K+ ATPase activity and calcium efflux through the cell membrane, resulting in an increase in intracellular sodium and calcium with a decrease in potassium. Release of cellular enzymes, as evidenced by this patient's elevated serum creatine kinase, indicates cell lysis, which is a sign of irreversible cell injury. This patient's elevated serum creatine kinase suggests the release of cellular enzymes, indicating cell lysis, which is a sign of late ischemia. A similar pattern of electrolyte changes occurs in ischemic myocardial cells (e.g., due to myocardial infarction).
questions.hint: Pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis are consistent with severe, prolonged limb ischemia.

questions.text: A 79-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being found unresponsive by the police. On arrival, he is apneic and there are no palpable pulses. Despite appropriate life-saving measures, he dies. Examination of the heart during autopsy shows normal ventricles with a sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum. A photomicrograph of a section of the heart obtained at autopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of iron granules would be consistent with hemochromatosis, which can also affect the heart and also appear as brown, sarcoplasmic perinuclear granules. However, other characteristic findings consistent with hemochromatosis are absent, such as fibrosis and cardiomegaly due to restrictive or dilated cardiomyopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Clumping of defective mitochondria is seen in mitochondrial myopathy, a rare genetic disorder that mainly affects organs with a high energy requirement including the heart. However, examination of the heart would show ventricular hypertrophy and/or dilatation, not a sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum. Moreover, the histological examination would show subsarcolemmal and intermyofibrillar mitochondria accumulation rather than the yellow-brown perinuclear inclusions seen here.

The mitochondrial accumulation that is seen in mitochondrial myopathy stains red with Gomori Trichrome stain, hence the commonly used descriptive term “ragged red fibers”.

C) CORRECT:

Lipofuscin granules, also known as wear-and-tear granules, are composed of yellow-brown pigmented granules and occur as a natural process with age. They are formed by the oxidation of phospholipid molecules and can be found in various organs (e.g., heart, liver, kidneys). Lipofuscin accumulates with age because it is never completely eliminated. Age-related mechanisms that can accelerate the accumulation of lipofuscin include the enhancement of autophagocytosis, a decline in intralysosomal degradation, and/or a decrease in exocytosis. A sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum is also a (physiological) sign of aging.

D) INCORRECT:

Aggregation of alpha-synuclein leads to neuronal death and is seen in conditions such as Parkinson disease, MSA, and Lewy body dementia. These neurodegenerative disorders mainly affect the brain and not the heart, which is the organ involved in this patient. Moreover, histological examination with H&E staining would show eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasmic inclusions rather than the yellow-brown pigmented inclusions seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Deposition of wild-type transthyretin is seen in senile amyloidosis and mainly affects the myocardium in elderly patients. However, senile amyloidosis would manifest with cardiomegaly due to myocardial thickening, not with a sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum. Moreover, histological examination with H&E staining would show amyloid proteins, which appear as glassy, eosinophilic, homogeneous deposits, not yellow-brown perinuclear inclusions.
questions.hint: The yellow-brown perinuclear inclusions indicated by the arrow are lipofuscin granules.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-day history of epigastric pain and vomiting. He has had similar episodes of epigastric pain in the past. He drinks 8 oz of vodka daily. Five days after admission, the patient develops aspiration pneumonia and sepsis. Despite appropriate therapy, the patient dies. At autopsy, the pancreas appears gray, enlarged, and nodular. Microscopic examination of the pancreas shows localized deposits of calcium. This finding is most similar to an adaptive change that can occur in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia, which predisposes tissues to metastatic calcification, but it would not cause dystrophic calcification.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease causes hyperphosphatemia due to decreased excretion of phosphorus. The excess phosphate promotes precipitation of calcium phosphate in healthy tissues, which is characteristic of metastatic calcification, but it would not cause dystrophic calcification.

C) CORRECT:

Congenital CMV infection disrupts normal cellular differentiation and apoptosis mechanisms, resulting in diffuse inflammatory damage and necrosis in tissues. Developing nervous tissue is particularly susceptible to damage, and the damaged areas undergo dystrophic calcification, resulting in the distinctive periventricular calcification seen in congenital CMV infections. Unlike metastatic calcification, dystrophic calcification is localized to damaged or necrotic tissue and occurs in patients with normal serum calcium and phosphate levels. Further examples of dystrophic calcification include calcific aortic stenosis, calcified atherosclerotic plaques, and psammoma bodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D intoxication causes hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. Hypercalcemia predisposes healthy tissues to metastatic calcification, not dystrophic calcification.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma is associated with increased osteoclast activity and osteolysis. Increased osteolysis in multiple myeloma leads to hypercalcemia, which in turn predisposes healthy tissue to metastatic calcification, but it would not cause dystrophic calcification.
questions.hint: This patient's history suggests chronic pancreatitis, which is confirmed by the dystrophic calcification seen on microscopic examination.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit after surgery following a motor vehicle collision. She has received a total of four units of packed red blood cells. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins. Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL and urine microscopy shows granular, muddy-brown casts. A renal biopsy specimen is obtained and examined under light microscopy. Which of the following reversible cellular changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fragmentation of the nucleus by endonucleases can also be seen as a consequence of hypoxic cell injury. The disruption of the cellular membrane and Ca2+ pumps causes an increase in intracellular Ca2+, which results in endonuclease activation and subsequent nuclear fragmentation (karyorrhexis) and dissolution (karyolysis). However, these are irreversible changes that result in cell death, not a reversible change.

B) INCORRECT:

Vacuolization of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is also seen in hypoxic cell injury. A decreased synthesis of ATP (shift to anaerobic glycolysis due to kidney tissue hypoxia) in the mitochondria impairs the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to an influx of Na+ and water into the cell and the ER. This causes the dilation of the ER and the formation of small vacuoles. However, vacuolization of the ER is an irreversible change rather than a reversible change.

Vacuolization of the endoplasmic reticulum should not be confused with cytoplasmic vacuolization, which is a reversible change.

C) INCORRECT:

Rupture of lysosomes by phospholipases is also seen in hypoxic cell injury. The disruption of the cellular membrane and Ca2+ pumps causes an increase in intracellular Ca2+, which results in phospholipase activation and subsequent damage to the lysosomal membrane. However, lysosome rupture is an irreversible cellular change, not a reversible change.

D) CORRECT:

Mitochondrial swelling due to hydropic degeneration is one of the earliest reversible changes following hypoxic cell injury. Acute hypoxia results in depletion of ATP in cells, causing a switch to anaerobic glycolysis. The energy generated by this reaction is much less than that generated by oxidative phosphorylation, causing ATP levels to further decrease and resulting in impairment of the Ca2+ pump and Na+/K+ ATPase. Decreased Na+/K+ ATPase activity causes an influx of Na+ and water into the cell, resulting in cellular and mitochondrial swelling. Other reversible changes of cell injury include membrane blebbing, nuclear chromatin clumping, and detachment of ribosomes and polysomes.

E) INCORRECT:

The release of cytochrome c from the inner mitochondrial membrane is also seen in hypoxic cell injury. The increased intracellular calcium that occurs due to impaired Ca2+-ATPase pump leads to increased calcium in the mitochondria, which triggers cytochrome c release from the mitochondrial membrane into the cytoplasm, where it activates caspases and leads to apoptosis. The release of cytochrome c is an irreversible step of cell injury, not reversible.

F) INCORRECT:

Degradation of cell membrane phospholipids by phospholipases can also be seen in hypoxic cell injury. A decreased synthesis of ATP (shift to anaerobic glycolysis due to tissue hypoxia) in the mitochondria impairs the Ca2+-ATPase pump, leading to an increase in intracellular Ca2+. This cytoplasmic Ca2+ activates phospholipases, which degrade the plasma membranes. However, the degradation of membrane phospholipids is an irreversible cellular change, not a reversible change.

Plasma membrane blebbing is a reversible change seen in hypoxic cell injury.

G) INCORRECT:

Dissolution of cellular chromatin (karyolysis) by endonucleases can also be seen in hypoxic cell injury. The disruption of the cellular membrane and Ca2+ pumps causes an increase in intracellular Ca2+, which results in endonuclease activation. However, endonuclease-mediated chromatin disruption and dissolution is an irreversible cellular change, not a reversible one.

H) INCORRECT:

Protease-induced cytoskeletal damage is also seen in hypoxic cell injury. The disruption of the cellular membrane and Ca2+ pumps causes an increase in intracellular Ca2+, activating proteases such as calpain that damage the cytoskeleton. However, cytoskeleton damage is an irreversible, not a reversible damage.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of acute kidney injury (hypovolemia, elevated serum creatinine, and granular, muddy-brown casts on urinalysis), which is most likely caused by hypoxic cell injury due to decreased renal perfusion. Hypoxic cell injury is characterized by reversible (early) and irreversible (late) findings.

questions.text: An investigator is studying patients with an autosomal dominant mutation in the long arm of chromosome 10. This mutation alters the structure of CD95 receptors and impairs the binding of a ligand to this receptor. These patients are at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Partial albinism is a congenital manifestation of Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LYST), not by a mutation of the CD95 receptor or a defective extrinsic apoptosis pathway.

B) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid aplasia is a characteristic manifestation of DiGeorge syndrome, resulting in congenital hypocalcemia. However, DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a microdeletion at chromosome 22, not by a mutation of the CD95 receptor on chromosome 10 or a defective extrinsic apoptosis pathway.

C) CORRECT:

Mutations in the Fas receptor (CD95 receptor) or the Fas ligand can cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS). Fas-FasL signaling is essential for proper thymic medullary negative selection, whereby caspases are activated, initiating apoptosis of T lymphocytes. Defects in this pathway lead to proliferation of antigen-specific, autoreactive lymphocyte lineages and result in hepatomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly as well as autoimmunity. Autoimmune cytopenia is an especially common manifestation of ALPS.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is associated with many genetic abnormalities, including such that affect transcription factors (e.g., retinoic acid receptor), tumor suppressors (e.g., p53), and cell signaling pathways (e.g., RAS). While mutations of the CD95 receptor are associated with an increased risk of lymphomas, AML is not caused by this genetic defect.

E) INCORRECT:

Several primary immunodeficiency syndromes are associated with diabetes mellitus (DM), including IPEX syndrome and autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS). Similar to CD95 receptor defects, mutations in AIRE (APS) disrupt the maturation of T lymphocytes in the thymus, leading to the formation of autoreactive T cells. Genetic defects in FOXP3 (IPEX syndrome) cause dysfunction or deficiency of regulatory T cells. The mutation of the CD95 receptor that is seen here, however, is not known to cause DM.

F) INCORRECT:

The absence of pus formation is a manifestation of leukocyte adhesion deficiency-1 (LAD1), which is caused by an autosomal recessive inherited mutation in the integrin subunit beta-2 (ITGB2) gene. Mutations in this gene result in a defect in CD18 but not in the CD95 receptor or a defective extrinsic apoptosis pathway.
questions.hint: CD95 (Fas) receptors are death receptors that activate the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after having a seizure. Over the past 3 days, he has had a fever and worsening headaches. This morning, his wife noticed that he was irritable and demonstrated strange behavior; he put the back of his fork, the salt shaker, and the lid of the coffee can into his mouth. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows diffuse hyperreflexia and an extensor response to the plantar reflex on the right. A T2-weighted MRI of the brain shows edema and areas of hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe. Which of the following is most likely the primary mechanism of the development of edema in this patient?

choices.text: Release of vascular endothelial growth factor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Release of vascular endothelial growth factor is one of the pathologic mechanisms of edema in brain tumors. This patient’s headache, seizure, and focal neurologic deficits are early signs of a brain tumor. However, an acute onset of symptoms and fever are more consistent with an infectious etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Cellular retention of sodium leading to fluid retention and cellular swelling is the pathologic mechanism of cytotoxic edema, a complication of acute ischemic stroke. Ischemic stroke can manifest with headache, seizure, and focal neurologic findings (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex). However, T2-weighted MRI in acute ischemic stroke typically shows hyperintensity with no hemorrhages. Furthermore, an acute ischemic stroke would not explain this patient's fever.

C) CORRECT:

Breakdown of endothelial tight junctions causing damage to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is the pathologic mechanism underlying vasogenic edema. Disruption of the BBB leads to extravasation of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space of the cerebral parenchyma, leading to increased intracranial pressure and neuronal dysfunction. This mechanism of edema development can also be due to other inflammatory conditions, metastasis, trauma, or lead poisoning.

The patient's behavioral change (putting the fork, salt shaker, and coffee can lid in his mouth) is characteristic of hyperorality, a finding in Kluver-Bucy syndrome. This condition is a possible complication of HSV encephalitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Degranulation of eosinophils is part of the pathologic mechanism of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction is characterized by tissue swelling and edema due to increased histamine release and increased vascular permeability. However, this mechanism does not play a role in the pathophysiology of cerebral edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased hydrostatic pressure is the pathologic mechanism underlying hypertensive encephalopathy, which causes severe headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex). However, hypertensive encephalopathy does not typically cause fever. Furthermore, this patient’s blood pressure is within the normal range.
questions.hint: The patient’s history of fever, headaches, seizure, focal neurologic findings (e.g., hyperreflexia and extensor response to plantar reflex), and MRI showing edema and hemorrhage in the temporal lobe suggest HSV encephalitis.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of lower back pain and lower extremity weakness for 3 weeks. Over the past week, he has also found it increasingly difficult to urinate. He has a history of prostate cancer, for which he underwent radical prostatectomy 8 years ago. His prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was undetectable until a routine follow-up visit last year, when it began to increase from 0.8 ng/mL to its present value of 64.3 ng/mL (N < 4). An MRI of the spine shows infiltrative vertebral lesions with a collapse of the L5 vertebral body, resulting in cord compression at L4–L5. The patient receives one dose of intravenous dexamethasone and subsequently undergoes external beam radiation. Which of the following cellular changes is most likely to occur as a result of this treatment?

choices.text: Intercalation of neighbouring DNA base pairs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonionizing radiation (e.g., UV radiation) causes covalent binding between adjacent pyrimidines, leading to dimer formation (most commonly thymine dimers). These dimers create bulky helix distortions, impairing normal base pairing during replication, which increases the risk of developing mutations. Nonionizing radiation is not used for external beam radiation therapy for cancer; rather it is the causative agent for skin cancers.
Image Description:

UV light (abbreviated as h×ν) causes damage to the DNA, most commonly by dimerisation of adjoining thymine bases: the C=C double bonds are coupled to form a cyclobutane ring (red). A thymine dimer immediately interrupts DNA replication.

B) INCORRECT:

Vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine, vinblastine) are chemotherapeutic agents that disrupt microtubule assembly by binding to β-tubulin. This disruption prevents the formation of the mitotic spindle, causing cell cycle arrest. Vinca alkaloids are most commonly used to treat solid tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas.
Image Description:

Overview of common chemotherapeutic agents and their molecular targets.

C) INCORRECT:

Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) are chemotherapeutic agents that destroy cells through intercalation between neighboring DNA base pairs. DNA intercalation leads to double-strand breaks and impaired replication. Anthracyclines also inhibit topoisomerase II, which prevents repair of coil relaxation and is lethal to the cell. Anthracyclines are most commonly used for solid tumors, including breast and lung cancer, as well as leukemias and lymphomas.
Image Description:

Overview of common chemotherapeutic agents and their molecular targets.

D) CORRECT:

Ionizing radiation (e.g., gamma irradiation, x-ray) causes ionization of the water component of cells and the resultant generation of hydroxyl radicals. Hydroxyl radicals are a type of reactive oxygen species that attack the DNA backbone and bases. These reactions cause DNA single-strand breaks and, most deleteriously, DNA double-strand breaks, which are very difficult for the cell to repair, leading to cell death.

DNA double-strand breaks may also cause malignant transformation due to faulty cell repair, leading to leukemia (e.g., AML, CLL), papillary thyroid cancer, osteosarcoma, and liver angiosarcoma later in life.
Image Description:

The radiosensitivity of cells varies with cell cycle phase. The image here shows the phases in which radiation results in chromosome aberration (yellow), apoptosis (blue), or mitotic arrest (green).

Cells in the G2 and M phase demonstrate the highest radiosensitivity, whereas cells in the G1 and S phases generally show radioresistance.

E) INCORRECT:

Formation of DNA crosslinks is the mechanism by which alkylating chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide, busulfan) destroy malignant cells. The presence of DNA crosslinks results in impaired DNA replication of the malignant cells. Alkylating agents are used for a wide variety of malignancies, including brain tumors, leukemias, and lymphomas.
Image Description:

Overview of common chemotherapeutic agents and their molecular targets.
questions.hint: External beam radiation is a form of ionizing radiation that causes apoptosis of cancer cells through the induction of DNA double-strand breaks.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past 30 minutes. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and atrial fibrillation. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Within one minute of the onset of this patient's symptoms, the cells in his right anteromedial cortical surface enlarge significantly. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the described cellular change?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of lysosomes is a part of the pathophysiology of irreversible cellular injury. The breakdown of lysosomal membranes causes the leakage of lysosomal enzymes into the cytosol. Activation of these enzymes leads to enzymatic digestion of cellular proteins, RNA, and DNA (i.e., autolysis). Although the rupture of lysosomes would lead to necrosis and cellular swelling, it would not occur within one minute of the onset of hypoxia.

B) INCORRECT:

The influx of extracellular calcium due to cell membrane rupture is a part of the pathophysiology of irreversible cellular injury. Intracellular calcium results in the activation of a number of enzymes (phospholipases, proteases, endonucleases) that have deleterious effects on the cell. Increased intracellular calcium also facilitates apoptosis by the induction of caspases and an increase in mitochondrial permeability. However, none of these mechanisms would occur within one minute of the onset of hypoxia.

C) CORRECT:

Intracellular depletion of ATP is caused by oxygen deprivation (e.g., tissue ischemia) and results in cellular swelling, the first morphologic manifestation of early-stage (reversible) cellular injury. Swelling occurs due to the failure of energy-dependent ion pumps (Na+/K+ ATPase and Na+/Ca2+ exchanger) in the cell membrane, which interrupts ion and fluid homeostasis across the membrane, causing an influx of Na+ and water into the cell. Other reversible cell changes include ribosomal detachment, chromatin clumping, cell membrane blebbing, and the formation of myelin figures.

D) INCORRECT:

The release of pro-apoptotic proteins occurs due to the breakdown of the mitochondrial membrane and is a part of the pathophysiology of irreversible cellular injury. The mitochondria harbor several proteins that are capable of activating apoptotic pathways, including cytochrome C and caspases. Increased permeability of the mitochondrial outer membrane may result in leakage of these proteins and death by apoptosis. However, this would not occur within one minute of the onset of hypoxia. Also, apoptosis causes shrunken cells, not cellular swelling.

E) INCORRECT:

The breakdown of the cell membrane is a part of the pathophysiology of irreversible cellular injury that can occur due to hypoxia. Consequences of cell membrane defects include further loss of osmotic balance, influx of fluids and ions (particularly calcium), and release of intracellular contents into the serum. Although the breakdown of the cell membrane can lead to cellular swelling, it would not occur within one minute of the onset of hypoxia.
questions.hint: This patient's history and physical exam are indicative of brain ischemia (e.g., stroke, transient ischemic attack). Enlargement of this patient's brain cells occurring within one minute of the onset of hypoxia indicates a reversible cellular injury.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident as a restrained driver. His pulse is 145/min and blood pressure is 102/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dark bruising and discoloration over the right upper quadrant of his abdomen and right flank. The abdomen is guarded and markedly tender to palpation. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows lacerations and compression injuries in the right lobe of the liver. An emergency partial hepatectomy is performed. Ultrasonography on follow-up examination 6 months later shows that the liver has grown back to almost the original size. Microscopic examination of the newly formed liver tissue is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:
