Regenerative nodules are an irreversible response to chronic liver injury (e.g., due to hepatitis C or alcohol use disorder). The nodules are formed by bridging fibrosis, which occurs via stellate cells; continued fibrosis leads to cirrhosis of the liver if the stimulus is not removed. The development of regenerative nodules inhibits hepatic function and leads to shrinkage of the liver, not regrowth.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (trichrome stain; high magnification)

A regenerative nodule composed of a cluster of hepatocytes (purple overlay), extensive fibrosis (stained blue), and the portal triad (yellow overlay) can be seen.

Regenerative nodules and fibrous septa are characteristic features of liver cirrhosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy of hepatocytes is a cellular response usually caused by drugs or toxins. Although hepatocyte hypertrophy can also sometimes be seen in remnant tissue after liver resection, newly-formed liver tissue does not typically show increased cell size. Additionally, hypertrophy alone would not be sufficient to achieve full regeneration of the liver.
Image Description:

Cells demonstrate particular adaptive changes in response to environmental changes or increased or decreased tissue requirements.

Cells can increase in size but not in number as a response to increased demand, which is termed hypertrophy (e.g., in skeletal muscles as a response to muscle training; top of the image). Hyperplasia is an increase in cell number with unaltered cell size (e.g., the thyroid in persistent iodine deficiency; middle left). There are two types of atrophy. Atrophy (bottom left) is a decrease in cell number, whereas hypotrophy (cellular atrophy; bottom right) is a decrease in cell size. If cell differentiation is affected as a result of cellular adaptation, this is termed metaplasia (e.g., transformation of squamous epithelium into cylindrical, mucosal epithelium in chronic gastric acid reflux in the esophagus; middle right).

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive proliferation of fibroblasts is seen in liver cirrhosis (e.g., due to infection or alcohol use disorder). The presence of cytokines and other metabolites causes hepatic cells (e.g., stellate cells) to transform into myofibroblasts. The resulting remodeling of liver tissue leads to increased stiffness (due to excessive synthesis of collagenous fibers) and shrinkage of the liver, not regrowth. Partial liver resection would not lead to excessive fibroblast proliferation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Nodules of regenerating hepatocytes surrounded by regions of collagenous fibers can be seen. The proliferation of bile ducts is also visible within the connective tissue.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) CORRECT:

Liver tissue has the unique ability to regenerate after resection or trauma through replication of remaining hepatocytes and repopulation from progenitor cells, such that regenerated areas will show normal hepatic tissue on microscopic examination. Stimulation of stable cells (e.g., injured hepatocytes) results in the transition from the G0 to G1 phase. Regeneration begins at the periportal zone, advances to the mid-zonal hepatocytes, then to the centrilobular zone, and ends at the central veins. After regeneration, biliary epithelial and endothelial cells proliferate and an extracellular matrix is produced by stellate cells. Through this process, the liver can restore itself to its full mass and preserve its essential metabolic functions.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of liver tissue (H&E stain; approx. 300x)

The arrows are located within a hepatic lobule: Arrow 1 points to the central vein (which is not clearly identifiable in this image). Arrow 2 points to the portal triad (comprised of a branch of the portal vein, a branch of the proper hepatic artery, and an interlobular bile duct).

Arrow 1 indicates the direction of blood flow, whereas arrow 2 indicates the direction of bile flow.

E) INCORRECT:

An inflammatory infiltrate develops in response to infections or toxins. Although liver resections can cause inflammation (e.g., due to entry of infectious agents during surgery), this would manifest earlier in the post-surgical course (days to weeks rather than months), and fever would be expected. Inflammatory cells may be chronically present in response to toxins (e.g., in chronic alcohol use). However, chronic inflammation would lead to an increase of myofibroblasts in liver tissue, causing fibrosis and shrinkage rather than regrowth.
questions.hint: Hepatocytes, like the cells of many other glands, are stable cells that are capable of multiplying after becoming damaged.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after she slipped on ice and hit her head. She is conscious on arrival. She has not had her menses for the past 6 months and reports a weight gain of 4.5-kg (10-lb) during this period. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (191 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a bleeding, 6-cm laceration in the occipital region. Her serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is increased. An MRI of the brain shows an enlargement of the pituitary gland. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's MRI findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A prolactinoma, which is the most common tumor of the pituitary gland, can enlarge during pregnancy as a result of the hyperestrogenic state. However, patients with a prolactinoma are usually infertile without treatment because prolactinomas secrete prolactin, which causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and, subsequently, anovulation. This patient did not receive any therapy for hyperprolactinemia (e.g., bromocriptine therapy) in the past and presents in a pregnant state (amenorrhea with elevated β-hCG). A different explanation is, therefore, much more likely for this pregnant woman's pituitary enlargement.

B) INCORRECT:

A craniopharyngioma can cause amenorrhea as a result of infundibular stalk compression (disconnection hyperprolactinemia) and/or pituitary gland damage (hypopituitarism) as well as weight gain resulting from damage to the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus. However, a craniopharyngioma arises above the pituitary gland (suprasellar mass) and typically occurs in children (5–14 years) or older adults (50–75 years); it is not an enlargement of the pituitary gland as seen here and would be unlikely in a 36-year-old individual. Moreover, amenorrhea due to a craniopharyngioma would be associated with infertility.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hypophysitis most commonly occurs in late pregnancy or the postpartum period and would manifest as pituitary gland enlargement on MRI. However, patients with autoimmune hypophysitis would have headaches and features of hypopituitarism such as adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, or diabetes insipidus. Moreover, autoimmune hypophysitis is a rare condition; there are other more common causes of pituitary enlargement in pregnancy that should be considered.

D) CORRECT:

The most likely cause of an incidentally discovered pituitary gland enlargement during pregnancy is functional lactotroph hyperplasia. Serum estrogen, which steadily increases during pregnancy, stimulates pituitary lactotrophs, resulting in lactotroph hyperplasia and increased prolactin production. This lactotroph hyperplasia can cause up to 40% increase from pregestational volume by the end of pregnancy. Of note, the number of thyrotrophs and corticotrophs remains unchanged and the number of somatotrophs and gonadotrophs decreases during pregnancy. The pituitary gland regains its normal pregestational size and cell-ratio at ∼ 6 months postpartum.

Physiological pituitary enlargement can also result from gonadotroph hyperplasia, which is a potential finding in puberty (due to hypothalamic GnRH production) and after menopause (due to decreased circulating estrogen and loss of negative feedback).

E) INCORRECT:

A germ cell pinealoma can secrete β-hCG, as seen here. However, a pinealoma would be located near the dorsal midbrain; it is not an enlargement of the pituitary gland. Moreover, pinealomas most commonly arise in children and manifest with Parinaud syndrome, obstructive hydrocephalus, and/or precocious puberty, all of which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: In a woman of child-bearing age, weight gain and amenorrhea along with elevated serum β-hCG indicate pregnancy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease presents with a 3-day history of worsening pain in the right foot. The patient reports that the pain initially began as mild discomfort but has progressively worsened despite elevation and over-the-counter analgesics. Vital signs are BP, 95/60; P, 118; R, 22; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F). On examination, the second and third toes show gray-black discoloration with surrounding erythema, edema, and purulent discharge. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Local wound care and topical antibiotic ointment
Broad-spectrum antibiotics and urgent surgical consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Local wound care and topical antibiotic ointment are inadequate for wet gangrene with signs of sytemic infection.

B) INCORRECT:

While amputation may ultimately be necessary, immediate amputation is premature. The initial priority is stabilization with antibiotics and obtaining surgical consultation.

C) INCORRECT:

While revascularization may be necessary for underlying peripheral arterial disease, wet gangrene with signs of systemic infection requires immediate managment before considering revascularization.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with wet gangrene evidenced by gray-black discoloration, purulent discharge, and systemic signs including fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. Wet gangrene represents superinfection of necrotic tissue and requires immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics to address the systemic infection and urgent surgical consultation for debridement of necrotic tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is not first-line treatment and should not delay definitive management. This patient's systemic symptoms and infected necrotic tissue require immediate antibiotic therapy and surgical intervention.

questions.text: An investigator is studying intracellular processes in muscle tissue after denervation. A biopsy specimen is obtained from the biceps femoris muscle of an 82-year-old woman who sustained sciatic nerve injury. Investigation of the tissue specimen shows shrunken cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm, nuclear shrinkage, and plasma membrane blebbing. Which of the following best explains the muscle biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bcl-2 is an antiapoptotic protein from the Bcl-2 family that inhibits, not initiates, the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis by maintaining the impermeability of the mitochondrial membrane. Overexpression of Bcl-2 is seen in follicular lymphoma, in which impaired apoptosis leads to tumor growth. Proteins of the Bcl-2 family can have opposite effects on apoptosis: Bcl-2-associated death promoter protein (BAD) and Bcl-2-associated X protein (BAX) have a proapoptotic effect, whereas Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL have an antiapoptotic effect!

B) CORRECT:

The release of mitochondrial cytochrome c, initiated by the proapoptotic proteins BAX and BAD, plays a crucial part in the mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis. Cytochrome c leads to the activation of caspases, which cause the destruction of the cytoskeleton, enter the nucleus, and cause DNA laddering and nuclear fragmentation. This process visualizes as dense eosinophilic cytoplasm, nuclear shrinkage, and plasma membrane blebbing in microscopic studies.

C) INCORRECT:

Bcl-2-associated X protein (BAX) is a proapoptotic protein that is capable of forming a pore in the mitochondrial membrane, leading to activation of the mitochondrial pathway of apoptosis. Degradation of BAX would, therefore, inhibit apoptosis. This process is involved in tumor survival and progression. Proteins of the Bcl-2 family can have opposite effects on apoptosis: Bcl-2-associated death promoter protein (BAD) and BAX have a proapoptotic effect, whereas Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL have an antiapoptotic effect!

D) INCORRECT:

The denaturation of cytoplasmic proteins is a characteristic feature of cell necrosis. Biopsy findings in necrosis would show cellular swelling, cell membrane rupture, and inflammation, none of which is seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Fas/FasL is a complex of a death receptor and its ligand (FasL), which triggers the extrinsic death receptor pathway of apoptosis by directly activating caspases. Inhibition of Fas/FasL interaction would, therefore, decrease apoptosis.
questions.hint: Dense eosinophilic cytoplasm, pyknosis, and plasma membrane blebbing are features of programmed cell death (apoptosis).

questions.text: A 77-year-old man with hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and atrial fibrillation is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-hour history of nausea and flank pain. Two days after admission, he suddenly develops aphasia and left-sided paralysis. Despite appropriate life-saving measures, he dies. A photograph of a section of the spleen obtained at autopsy is shown. Microscopic examination of the pale region in the photograph shows preserved cellular architecture with eosinophilic cytoplasm and no visible nuclei. Which of the following pathological changes is most likely responsible for the splenic findings on autopsy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Coagulative necrosis occurs as a result of tissue ischemia in solid organs such as the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys (e.g., splenic infarction). Ischemia is characterized by decreased oxygen delivery, which reduces the amount of ATP produced via aerobic glycolysis. The hypoxic cells have to switch to anaerobic metabolism, which increases the production of lactic acid, resulting in acidosis. Acidosis causes denaturation of proteins (including proteolytic and particularly lysosomal enzymes), and this prevents the cell from dissolving (autolysis). For this reason, coagulative necrosis is characterized by a temporary preserved cellular architecture either without cell nuclei or with nuclei that are still undergoing karyolysis. See “Types of necrosis” table.

An infarction can be differentiated into two types: red infarct and pale infarct. A red infarct typically occurs due to venous occlusion in tissues with multiple blood supplies (e.g., intestine, liver, lung), and a pale infarct typically occurs in solid organs with a single (end-arterial) blood supply (e.g., kidney, spleen, heart).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (H&E stain; 150x magnification)

A large area of necrosis (green overlay) is visible. Necrotic glomeruli (green arrowheads) are also visible within a highly dense area of leukocytes (white overlay). This is in contrast to the appearance of a normal glomerulus (black arrowhead).

These findings are consistent with coagulative necrosis caused by renal infarction.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonenzymatic fat necrosis is most commonly seen in fatty tissue (e.g., breast, subcutaneous tissue) following blunt trauma or surgery. This patient’s ischemic infarct was in the spleen, in which nonenzymatic fat necrosis could not occur. Histologic examination of nonenzymatic fat necrosis would show lipid-laden macrophages with foreign body giant cells as well as fibrosis and dystrophic calcifications.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Necrotic adipocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) are visible as adipocytes with indistinct, irregular borders and absent nuclei. Unstained, lipid-filled cystic spaces are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). An inflammatory infiltrate is present (example indicated by arrowhead).

These findings are characteristic of fat necrosis of the breast. At a higher magnification, cholesterol clefts, foam cells, and multinucleated giant cells would also be visible.

C) INCORRECT:

Gangrenous necrosis is most commonly seen in patients with chronic limb ischemia (dry gangrene) or gastrointestinal tract ischemia (wet gangrene). A histologic examination of dry gangrene, which results from tissue ischemia, would show preservation of cellular architecture along with the absence of nuclei as seen in this patient. However, this patient's infarct was in the spleen, which is not subject to gangrenous necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

In liquefactive necrosis, lysosomal enzymes are released in order to degrade and liquefy necrotic material. Liquefactive necrosis is classically seen in cerebral infarctions and can also occur in bacterial abscesses (pyogenic renal abscesses), but this patient’s ischemic infarct was in the spleen, which is not subject to liquefactive necrosis. Histologic examination of the tissue affected by liquefactive necrosis would show liquified tissue (due to the release of hydrolytic and lysosomal enzymes) with multiple macrophages and cyst formation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (H&E stain)

Numerous cystic spaces and disintegration of the normal tissue architecture are visible. There is abundant cellular debris.

The extensive transformation of the tissue differentiates this case of liquefactive necrosis from one of coagulative necrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis is most commonly seen in blood vessels in patients with vasculitides or malignant hypertension. It is characterized by immune complex and/or fibrin deposition in the blood vessel wall. This patient’s ischemic infarct was in the spleen, which is not subject to fibrinoid necrosis. Histologic examination of fibrinoid necrosis would show protein-rich, eosinophilic acellular material in damaged vessels.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of arteriole in the lung tissues (H&E stain)

The wall of the arteriole exhibits annular deposition of amorphous and proteinaceous material, and inflammatory infiltrates.

These are the typical features of fibrinoid necrosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Caseous necrosis is associated with granulomatous infections such as nocardiosis, tuberculosis (including renal tuberculosis), and histoplasmosis. This patient’s ischemic infarct was in the spleen, which does not result in caseous necrosis. Granulomas typically appear as focal, round, or lobulated nodules with surrounding edema. Histologic examination of caseous necrosis would show acellular material that appears granular and is surrounded by macrophages, T-cells and giant cells.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

The image shows a granuloma with necrosis in the center (green outline), a surrounding layer of immune cells such as macrophages (B), and a peripheral layer (C), which consists of epitheloid cells. A giant cell (A) can also be seen.

This is the typical histopathological appearance of a caseating granuloma, which is seen in tuberculosis.
questions.hint: The photograph shows several pale, wedge-shaped splenic infarcts, which can manifest with flank pain and nausea. The most likely cause of the infarct in this patient was an embolus due to atrial fibrillation.
